ygData.subject: Re: Help with XOR? :(

Thanks, that helped immensely. I wasn't sure what troubleshooting
steps I c=
ould take next. I used Colin's (second) solution, and found a
bug in the ne=
twork code!

So now with weight mutation only, I'm able to find solutions u=
sually
within 40 generations (typically) using 50 individuals.

I'll contin=
ue with the topology-mutating operators, and see how it goes.

Thanks again=
!

--Rob

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wro=
te:
>
> Rob, I believe your topology is correct and should be able to solve=
 
> XOR.
> 
> One thing you might want to do as a sanity check is find a so=
lution 
> to XOR in a neural network textbook and plug it into your system =
and 
> run your network activation function it.  Or even better, run my 
> =
version of NEAT to create an XOR solution and then load that into 
> your s=
ystem and test it.
> 
> Then I would check into the weight mutations.  I wo=
uld try very 
> different uniform distribution sizes to see if one of them =
works.  
> It's possible your weight mutations are for some reason too big =
or 
> too small.
> 
> However, first let me know if your networks activate =
correctly on 
> solutions that you know should work.
